text:
Increasing outreach

I was more than a bit annoyed when I heard that at a recent daily meeting, when, in commenting on the success of your web-chat with young Egyptians, you asked why we did not do more of these and someone responded that they were glad to hear they had "permission" to do them. As I know you know, I have been pushing people to do this for some time and have made it quite clear that no permission is required.

Since prodding doesn't seem to work I now plan to "direct" each regional bureau to work with PA to develop a plan for weekly web-chats focused on issues of regional relevance and engaging the full range of DC based FSO's and subject matter experts, including those with language skills suited to each region. We invest an enormous amount in training our officers and this will help leverage that investment. This isn't brain surgery and can be done quite simply and efficiently if people put their minds to it.

In an effort to appeal to their enlightened self-interests I also plan to tell them that I will be providing you with a detailed report on this initiative.

My apologies for not having been able to get this going sooner.

text:
Cheryl::

I promised you I'd let you know the very moment I had made a decision on the Humphrey School.

And in what has been the most difficult career decision I have ever confronted, I have decided to accept their offer. It was so difficult because I cannot imagine a more meaningful and fulfilling position than the one I now hold. And I cannot imagine a more inspiring leader than the Secretary — or more support than that which I've received from you, and from others on her senior-level team.

I've always believed deeply that how one leaves a job is as important as how one executes his or her responsibilities while on the job, and I'm committed to ensuring that my transition does not impair the Department's humanitarian (or QDDR) work. To that end, and with the Congressional schedule very much in my mind, I have arranged with the University a midOctober start date, which should give me the chance to bring to closure a number of very important Bureau humanitarian initiatives and, more importantly, should give the Department adequate time to ensure a smooth transition. And I will do everything I possibly can to help you on that front.

Because news of this may get out, I'm planning to send the Secretary a personal note today (on which I will copy you), but I wanted to be sure you were the very first person to know.

Kind regards, Eric

PS I have tried to call Maria (who knew I was considering this), but she hasn't gotten back to me. I will email her as well if I do not hear back today.

text:
Jake:

A quick summary of what happened tonight in Dublin:

Cowen won the party vote of confidence tonight; the tally won't be made public (yet). Finance Minister Brian Lenihan publically supported the Taoiseach and looks to have improved his position in the party and for taking over FF having chosen the winning side today. Martin gave a strong speech in opposition before the vote and was congratulatory to Cowen publically afterward. He tendered his resignation (while stating he doesn't want anyone else to follow his lead), which Cowen "reluctantly" accepted. Both Cowen and Martin's remarks were complimentary toward each other and reaffirmed their friendship. Word is that the Taoiseach will take on the FM's portfolio.

I don't know who will travel to Munich in Martin's place--if it is the Taoiseach and Martin was on the calendar, we'd support a meeting with Cowen in lieu of Martin.

Best, Jason

text:
Statement

The Passing of Victoria DeLong

This morning I spoke with the family of Victoria DeLong, the Cultural Affairs Officer at our Embassy in Port-Au-Prince who lost her life in the earthquake. I expressed my sincerest condolences on behalf of the men and women of the State Department and the American people. This is one tragedy among so many. The United Nations has suffered grevious losses. And the Hatian people have endured unimaginable heartbreak. For the State Department, we have lost one of our own. Victoria was a veteran Foreign Service Officer who worked tirelessly to build bridges of understanding and respect between the people of the United State and the people of Haiti. She served her country with distinction and honor, and she will be sorely missed. Victoria's friends and colleagues at the Embassy are working day and night to support vital relief and recovery efforts, and our thoughts, our prayers, and our deepest thanks are with them as well. Along with the military personnel, the search and rescue teams, and all the aid and relief workers now deploying, they represent the unwavering commitment of the United States to stand with Haiti in its hour of need and in the hard days and years to come. My heart is with the DeLong family today, and with all those in Haiti and around the world who have lost loved ones and friends in this disaster.

text:
Dear Hillary:

I hope all is well personally. It's a torrid political situation for the Administration. Progressives are not in a good position on debts and deficits anywhere; or not in a good political position, as we have some good arguments.

I have been doing some writing and speaking about ten years since 9/11. Perhaps one of your staff can get a piece I wrote for London based Prospect magazine just published, entitled "Decade of Disorder".

Further to our last conversation, in the Autumn I am taking up the cause of youth unemployment, and will be chairing a short (hopefully sweet) blue-ribbon panel on the lost promise to young workers. But there is very little space in formal UK politics; parties can't have two leaders.

I have a couple of big decisions to take and it would be good if we could catch up when I am in DC 26-28 September (I am contributing to a Post conference on China at which I think your husband is interviewing Henry Kissinger). I will ask my office to contact yours but perhaps you could register the dates with your team.

Hope you get a break. Despite Assad and other problems I still think Arab Spring will work out. I am very concerned about Af-Pak and MEPP as they two great insolubles. As for EU it is not an advert for anything at the moment. The bond markets are capricious and unaccountable but they do capture truths about political uncertainty.

Best,

David

Suzanne

text:
Speaking for State

Meanwhile, chatter at the State Department is about the likely move of career Foreign Service officer Victoria Nuland, former ambassador to NATO and now special envoy for conventional forces in Europe, to be the department's spokeswoman.

The expected move was first reported Monday by our pal Laura Rozen at Yahoo News — though it's been in the works for a couple of months. The possibility has raised a few eyebrows in town because Nuland, who's married to political scientist and Washington Post columnist Robert Kagan , was principal national security adviser to Dick Cheney starting right after the invasion of Iraq, from July 2003 to July 2005. (Of course, we recall that Hillary Clinton was a backer of that war.)

On the other hand, during the Bill Clinton administration, Nuland was chief of staff to Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, a longtime Clinton pal.

Given Nuland's foreign policy chops, one would assume she will have ready, direct access to Secretary of State Clinton, which of late has not always been the case with spokespersons. Another question is whether Nuland will be the traveling spokesperson when Clinton goes overseas. That role has often been taken by longtime Clinton aide and former Senate press secretary Philippe Reines, who has also been the one sitting in when Clinton is interviewed by reporters.

Mike Hammer, now acting assistant secretary for public affairs, is still expected to be nominated to take that job on a permanent basis.

text:
Erica, Sam, Jake:

The Africa Bureau has taken the following steps in the past three hours to win support for the Libya vote in the UN Security Council.

Nigeria

We attempted to reach Foreign Minister Ajumogobia, but Embassy Abuja informed us he is in transit in Asia and was unavailable. Our Chargé reached out to Nigerian MFA Permanent Secretary Uhomoibhi, the number two at the Foreign Ministry and President Jonathan's point-man for UN Security Council coordination. Uhomoibhi hedged ultimately but said his government would decide its position at the highest levels and expressed hope that the decision would be the "right one."

South Africa

I reached out to South Africa's National Security Special Advisor to Zuma Welile Nhlapo, detailed the four parts of the draft resolution, and underscored the importance of standing up for liberty and democracy in Libya and pressuring Qaddafi to forestall further violent retribution against people seeking greater freedom. Although it was well after midnight in Pretoria, Nhlapo pledged to pass the message to colleagues working the issue. I underscored the urgency.

Separately, PDAS Yamamoto discussed our outreach strategy with Ambassador Gips in Pretoria, who told us that Minister of the Department of International Relations and Cooperation Mashabane could not be easily reached, as she was at the airport seeing off Aristide;

The South African Embassy in New York told USUN, we understand, that South Africa would vote with us. Regards, Johnnie Ambassador Johnnie Carson Assistant Secretary for African Affairs

text:
Israeli Ambassador Michael Oren called me today to complain about our comments today on the Jerusalem housing evictions. Saying that he was calling under instructions, he made comments on three basic themes:

1) The evictions of the Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah were purely a legal matter. These were illegal squatters. The case went all through the Israeli court system and was decided by the Supreme Court. This was not a provocation. If there was a provocation, it was when the illegal squatters stopped paying their rent.

2) Israel objects to the suggestion that this was a violation of the roadmap. Israel requests clarification of what part of the roadmap obligations the U.S. believes were violated.

3) Israel rejects the suggestion that the timing was connected to the Fatah Party Congress. There is no connection.

I undertook to convey the demarche and made our response about how this really is unhelpful, especially at this time.

Jeffrey Feltman Acting Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

text:
Hi Claire and Huma - Please pass on to the Secretary.

Dear Madam Secretary,

Faith and I are now well settled in Baku. Given the terrible events of the past few weeks, I wanted to bring to your attention a heartening anecdote, which shows that most people in this part of the world feel positively about America. Faith and I visited the city of Lankeran this past weekend. Lankeran is located about 20 miles from the Iranian border and is religiously more conservative than the rest of the country. We went there because Azerbaijan is hosting the Under 17 Women's World Cup, and the opening game between the United States and France, was held there in a filled 12000 seat stadium. We are using this tournament to emphasize the importance of young women in sports and the importance of team sports to later life. During the game we walked around the track surrounding the field to a group of Azerbaijani girls, who had been invited by a local Peace Corps volunteer and who were all decked out in American regalia. They were quite excited to meet us. But what was more amazing was that walking back as we passed by each section, the entire crowd cheered loudly. Faith was like "Mother America" waving to the crowd! She is the one who should be Ambassador! We were very heartened. It is easy to get a little bit discouraged when things go badly in a lot of countries, but little things such as this experience reminded us that a lot of people still look to America. The game itself was hard fought and ended in a 0-0 tie. The U.S. still has a good chance to win it all.

All the best,. Dick

text:
Cheryl/Pat

This is probably already on your radar, but wanted to make sure I flagged.

Beth Jones was designated as Acting A/S for NEA on June 1 (the day after Jeff vacated the position). As I understand it, under the Vacancies Reform Act, she can only retain the Acting title for 210 days unless a nominee is pending before Congress.

Her 210 days will run up on December 28th but can be extended if someone is nominated when Congress gets back early January.

I know this is odd timing given the transition. PPO has not said anything to me about this yet either.

I can speak with L about whether there is any leeway in extending the 210 days particularly given transition. Also I will confirm that under the Vacancy Reform Act, if Beth's clock does run out, then Liz Dibble in her capacity as PDAS can automatically serve as Acting if we want to go that route.

Thanks. Heather

text:
Cheryl It may be worth putting together a small group to think through the issue in some depth to decide whether there is a more proactive strategy that may be possible and/or worth engaging in one or more countries : 1. Define human rights challenges around gay communities in many of our partner countries 2. Define the social political context (ie: how does civil society and the political/legislative activity converge or not converge) 3. Potential role of Judicial response (eg: Adult Disability Act in US) 4. Role of multilateral and normative bodies We are quietly doing this in PEPFAR over the next two months to assess whether we can work behind the politics to increase the "safe space" for our populations seeking and/or in care (increase identification, entry and retention).

text:
Senator Frist asked me to convey to the Secretary on his behalf that he has decided not to seek a second term on the MCC board when his current term expires this November. He's been weighing the decision carefully for several months, and ultimately reached the conclusion that because MCC is in good shape in terms of both Administration and Congressional support—compared to when we started in late 2007—he feels that it is the right moment to reallocate his time to some other initiatives and projects that he has had to decline or delay, many in the global health and development area. The September 15th board meeting will be our last.

He would have gotten in touch personally, but he is travelling with his family in Africa and the UK until next week, and he wanted her to hear the news from him first. He says that he of course looks forward to continuing to work with her on issues they have discussed.

He has let MCC CEO Daniel Yohannes and Senator McConnell know, and I have begun the process of informing other board members via Plus Ones. I was waiting to speak with you before contacting others at State, but will begin to do so.

Talk to you soon—

Mauro.

Mauro De Lorenzo Vice President, Freedom and Free Enterprise John Templeton Foundation 300 Conshohocken State Road, Suite 500 West Conshohocken PA 19428, USA +1 610 941 2828 office

text:
Dear George: Simply put, I am sorry to see you go. I have the deepest respect, admiration and gratitude for the service you provided our country as Special Envoy for Middle East Peace — not to mention the rest of your incredible career. I applaud your tireless efforts to advance our shared vision of a comprehensive peace between Israelis and Palestinians and Israel and all of its Arab neighbors.

I had the privilege of seeing up close the unique combination of diplomatic insight and political pragmatism you brought to this most complex of foreign policy challenges.

The differences between the parties — as you have often noted — are deep and serious, requiring time and good faith negotiations to overcome. While we have not yet achieved our goal, your work was a vital contribution to the framework of a peace agreement that will one day emerge. And as we build on your work, all of us will heed your call to remain patient and persistent in the pursuit of peace.

Your service was in the highest tradition of our country, and provided an example of integrity and honor for all of us. You represent the finest of American statesmanship and diplomacy. All of us at the State Department will miss your steady leadership and wise counsel, but I know you will remain a passionate advocate for peace and I look forward to drawing on your advice and insights as we proceed.

text:
Issa targets Hillary: Big mistake

By Brent Budowsky - 10/10/12 04:03 PM ET

Don't miss the story in The Hill "Issa closes in on Clinton" about Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) aiming at his biggest target yet, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. The story is correct. The Issa strategy will backfire. It will prove to be a disaster. House Republicans, whose brand is not exactly soaring with voters, are making a huge mistake using congressional hearings as a partisan weapon to exploit a national tragedy to attack one of the most admired and respected public servants in the nation.

There is now an independent and nonpartisan investigation of exactly what happened in Libya. A partisan witch-hunt by Republicans using taxpayer money against Secretary Clinton, as a partisan weapon in the closing days of an election, to exploit a tragedy to score political points is exactly what the American people believe has gone wrong with Washington, and is exactly why the Republican brand is in such disrepute with many voters.

Many independent voters will be offended. Many female voters will be offended. Many voters tired of their taxpayer money being wasted for political shenanigans will be offended.

text:
Hi! Hope you all are getting some R&R as the summer wanes.

Your Africa trip has generated a lot of visibility and momentum on women's issues. I wanted to follow up on an idea we discussed, when we met a few months ago, for raising the profile of women's issues and creating a unique platform for you in the U.S.

You may recall that Melanne and I were developing ideas for holding events to connect people working on women's issues around the world, and to raise the visibility of the issues in the US.

Whitney Williams has joined us to flesh out a vision for a series of conferences that would bring together policymakers and experts from the field with women you have met around the world - and people at the grassroots level in this country.

Each conference would be followed by a special event featuring musical, cultural and culinary celebrities (yep, celebrity chefs) from the U.S. and other countries to generate visibility online and in the entertainment media, which would reach a lot more people than the policy conference alone.

These events would create connections among people who often work in isolation, and generate ideas for improving policies and practices. They'd also inspire and engage a whole new generation to get involved in global women's issues.

text:
If we can get the language changed (e.g. illegal vs illegitimate) and a commitment from the Pals not to pursue similar resolution, we have a rationale for abstention, including with the Israelis — although they won't like it. In that connection, it could be decisive with the Pals if the Europeans were to say that they would abstain if this were brought to the UNSC under current circumstances. We would have to work it hard with relevant folks here and in Israel.

If we are unable to change the language, on balance I would veto. If we abstain on a resolution that is contrary to our position, after we have suggested we would veto, it will appear that we are acting in reaction to the situation on the ground. I think that would make us appear weak rather than strong. It is hard to articulate a rationale for abstention that does not suggest that this is a retreat in response to events. In Israel, that would be seen as the first manifestation of the "post- Mubarak" order, and reinforce the narrative of abandonment, perhaps contributing to an atmosphere in Israel that produces unhelpful steps of their own in reaction to the current crisis.

text:
Republicans are overjoyed. Democrats are tearing out their hair. Twitter may explode.

A couple thoughts and some perspective:

1) The latest Gallup poll covers the dates of Oct. 11-Oct. 17 which means it is only capturing one day of post-debate sentiment. We won't have a full post-debate sample until Tuesday (Oct. 16-22). I will leave it to Gary to explain any other details about polling methodology etc.

2) There is an expectation by many that the race will tighten back up next week, thanks in part to an expected boost in Democratic enthusiasm.

3) That said, if Romney retains a lead in this poll — or any other airworthy poll, it suggests that Romney's big win in Denver and his solid performance at Hofstra helped him to finally clear the "acceptability" bar with those wavering Obama 2008 voters he needs to win over. The Romney campaign has long held that this race will resemble 1980 where the race remained very close until the very end when it broke dramatically in Reagan's favor. Like Romney, Regan's big break came from a solid debate performance. However, the political polarization in this country is much more intense and solidified than it was in 1980.

text: Had dinner last night (Tuesday, February 16) with Joschka Fischer. We had an interesting conversation on Iran and Saudi Arabia, among other things. (As you know Fischer is now director of the Nabucco pipeline project.) On Iran, harsh, targeted sanctions are absolutely necessary, but are most effective diplomatically when always coupled with an offer to negotiate. The iron fist in the velvet glove approach achieves several objectives: According to Fischer's intelligence, Ahmanijehad wished some negotiated settlement but was blocked. The regime has splits at the top. Perhaps true, perhaps not. But constantly pushing negotiations alongside sanctions puts additional pressure on internal divisions, whatever they are. Extending an open hand while brandishing a stick closes diplomatic and political room to maneuver for Iran: Its refusal to accept the open hand justifies application of the stick. Even when sanctions are enforced it always remains useful to say another way is open. The damage done to Iran is therefore the result of its own choice. This approach also aids the opposition. A purely condign sanctions strategy can contribute to the regime's will to punish and tighten repression. Talking of regime change, of course, undermines the cause of regime change. It is a gift to the regime. The opposition is a new factor in the Iran equation that must be taken into account on the political and moral level. Pushed to the wall, the regime may feel compelled to repress, which might involve thousands or tens of thousands of political killings. On Saudi Arabia, Fischer points out that if Iran develops nuclear weaponry the Saudis already have their own bomb. The Saudis invested in Pakistan's nuclear weaponry partly for this eventuality; that's their bomb in reserve.

Dear Ms. Adashek,

Please pass this message on to Vernon Jordan as soon as possible.

Dear Vernon,

I hope you are well.

This week Hillary Clinton will visit Hungary. I suggest that she should be very careful to avoid an embarrassment. The press is already full with remarks that her visit will be seen as an approval for the Hungarian government and Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

Cheryl

Just to let u know that David has made a tremendous impression on the people of Camp Ashraf. Although the situation remains dangerous and there's fear of another Iraqi raid, there's also real progress.

Carolyn Ennis of UNHCR has started to register residents as "People of Concern" and each of the residents is completing an individual application. There's a significant chance that Canada may accept additional people, including their own passport holders, in the near future. The hope is that this will create a pipeline to allow a larger exodus if the US FTO is lifted.

Both the EU and the UNHCR have used this progress to argue that closing Ashraf by January 1 is "unrealistic" and the relocation/registration progress are addressing Malaki's concerns. The immediate problem is to get the UNHCR the logistical help that they need and get some personnel in the Camp to make another attack difficult.

text:
Sorry, with text this time...

The Passing of Ambassador Jerome Shestack

I am deeply saddened by the passing of my friend Jerry Shestack. He was a committed public servant and a dogged defender of human rights. Countless women and men are better off because of Jerry.

Jerry served the cause of human rights for more than half a century. He made a lasting impression as Ambassador to the U.N. Human Rights Commission where he launched the U.N. Working Group to investigate disappearances under oppressive regimes. Under President George H.W. Bush, he served with distinction on the delegation to the Moscow Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and on the Presidential-Congressional Commission to Improve the Effectiveness of the United Nations.

As President of the American Bar Association and in the years following he set the standard for how civil society leaders can promote human rights.

He was unwavering in his commitment to the highest of American values and international, human rights standards. Jerry was an effective advocate for the causes—and people—he cared about because he had a rare mix of wonderful qualities: optimism, resilience, humor, a thick skin, and a way of making everyone feel at ease.

Today my thoughts and prayers are with Jerry's beloved wife, Marciarose, and their two children, Jennifer and Jonathan.

Madame secretary (that's still fun to say):

I hope you're doing well and at least getting a little down time this summer.

I have some news for you and a quick question to ask.

In a couple weeks I will be leaving steve's company to take a job in mayor villaraigosa's administration. Specifically I'll be the chief deputy mayor and one of the top two staffers in the city. text:
Statement

Bombings in Moscow

Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims of this morning's bombings in Moscow, their families, and all the people of Russia. This brutal assault on innocent civilians is another reminder that terrorism is a threat to peace-loving people everywhere and must be met with unwavering resolve. I will offer my personal condolences to Foreign Minister Lavrov later today in Ottawa. Together with our G8 partners, we will discuss how to improve international counterterrorism coordination and cooperation. I was in Moscow earlier this month, and I know the resilience and determination of the Russian people. The United States stands with them today and everyday in solidarity against violent extremism in all its forms.

I've attached a copy of a draft op ed about the creation and work of the Center for Strategic Counter-terrorism Communications (CSCC) that Richard LeBaron and I have been working on. We want to try and get it published in the next few weeks in the run up to 9/11. It's an important initiative and we'd like to heighten awareness of State's contributions in this area in the hopes of maintaining support for it in the future.

Among other things, I think CSCC provides a good example of your approach to these most difficult challenges and to public diplomacy more broadly: appropriately define your audience; go where they hang out; use all the tools we have, including digital media; deliver messages which resonate; be sure our narrative is part of the debate; and provide platforms for engagement. It all seems so incredibly obvious to me that I was always surprised when we encountered resistance both within State and from those on the outside.

Let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Happy Birthday!

I have to head to NY very early in the morning and wanted to wish you a Happy Birthday and a successful and safe trip to Pakistan. It is clearly one of the most important missions you've ever embarked on --- and there have been many.

We had a good gathering at the Mahmood's for the new foundation. Holbrooke was in good form. I think the discussion went a long way to persuading some of the skeptics that it was important to get the foundation off the ground and to sustain it over the years to come. I'm going to meet with some of the women as a follow up. Some have projects that they are already supporting; others feel we (AID) doesn't listen to advice on the ground, etc, etc. It can't hurt and may even help!

Whitney told me she talked to you about the Women's Fund. Yes, we are planning to have DRC be one of the key areas to target support.

As they say in Ukraine, "mnohaya lita" -- wishing you many years to come!

Rosemary: I just spoke to AU Chairperson Jean Ping, who is Mauritania. He is prepared to fly to Paris tomorrow at the invitation of the French but does not have his own Diane.

Ellen Powell,

I have been in touch with our ambassador in Mauritania, Jo

have stressed to Ping the importance of having African representation at the Paris meeting and the need for the AU to embrace and wrap itself fully in yesterday's UNSC resolution.

The five African heads of state were slated (under their original schedule) to meet in Mauritanian on Saturday evening and then travel to Libya on Sunday. Without going into any detail, I told Ping that no mechanism had been put in place for air clearances and that it was absolutely imperative to touch base with the UN and all appropriate authorities before any of the African presidents attempted to travel to Libya on Sunday. I also told Ping his participation in the Paris meeting would provide him with additional information and might convince him and his colleagues that a trip to Libya was not necessary. When we receive further word from Mauritania about the AU travel plans, I will let you know. Johnnie

text: I would be careful with the commercial farming. Many African leaders support it because it's good for their cronies. Paul Collier has been one of the most vocal supporters of commercial farming - mostly because of the success of Brazil. Our USAID colleagues are much less supportive because historically it doesn't have as much benefit for the poor as working directly with rural farmers. I think the best way to frame this issue is to say: we support small holder farmers and that's what our programs will emphasize; but, if we see an opportunity for commercial farms to also help achieve our goal of lifting 100 million out of hunger and poverty, then we will support it. In general, commercial farms usually benefit those who are above the poverty line - not those below it. Best, Matt

text:
They have now accepted our bail money, thus removing the roadblock that has bedeviled us for the past two days. The lawyers and our people are going back to the court, then to the prosecutors' office for some final paperwork.

If this goes okay, we will stage our amcits and third country personnel in about thirty minutes to depart.

We had some back and forth with the plane last night and ended up paying a $8000 fine for our allegedly improper flight plan. text:
Cheryl, Jake:

Despite the nailbiting finale, the Human Rights Council reentry has been remarkably successful. The tally, with returns still coming in:

1. Goldstone-report deferred through extraordinary political work by all of you 2. Freedom of Expression--tonsensus--a landmark achievement in suggesting that there is indeed a universal understanding of freedom of expression that can cut across cultural lines 3. Honduras: consensus 4. Womens' Equality-consensus 5. Human Security issues: US took forward leaning posture USG engaged across the board and got the results it wanted--5 for 5--plus appeared principled and balanced To be honest if we had gotten any 2 of these, I would have felt relieved. Instead we ran the table. There was a stunning performance by 10-DRL-L-AmEmbassy Geneva and various regional bureaus, particularly NEA and WHA and AF, as well as EUR. The State Department at its finest and multilateral diplomacy executed at a macro and micro level. Brimmer, Nossel, Posner all were outstanding as were our folks in Geneva.

And this is in our first reengagement. It should get better as we gain more experience.

Harold Hongju Koh The Legal Adviser U.S. Department of State 2201 C St. NW Washington, DC 20520 202 647 9598 o

text:
Please flag for MG

As they committed during Indian Commerce Minister Sharma's visit earlier this month and projected as far back as Minister Fahim's September 2011 visit to India, Pakistan's cabinet approved a new negative list with India today (before the end of February).

The new negative list of 1209 restricted product lines (of about 6800 tradeable categories) replaces the previous positive list of about 1900 allowable product lines. This more than doubling of tradeable goods roughly meets my expectations but may be a disappointment given the wild hopes of some in New Delhi, especially given that the negative list rejected by cabinet two weeks ago included only 636 products. The late additions reflect last minute pressure from the autoparts, machinery, and textiles industries. Implementation is set to occur within one month, and the goal is still to phase out the list by end 2012 and to announce Most Favored Nation status at that point. (Comment: Though I am skeptical that they will be able to move that fast given the political calendar and industry pressures. Other countries,

including India, maintain a limited sensitive list and are considered technically WTO. compliant.)

This is real and historic progress for Indo-Pakistan relations, a big victory for Zardari's government, and a real achievement for the New Silk Road vision.

James C. Schwemlein Office of the Special Representative for Afghanistan & Pakistan

text:
Jean-Louis and I had a lengthy conversation today covering a broad range of subjects relating to your interest in supporting textile and apparel activity in Haiti. He has subsequently shared with me a number of specific materials on the Haiti project, including an email of yours which highlights the objectives of the project and a suggested timeline, as well as the business proposal made by Hansoll. When I digest these latter materials, I will consider myself in a much better position to make responsive recommendations to you.

As I communicated to Jean-Louis, I am happy to be helpful to you and the State Department on this project. I can make myself available a couple of days a month for meetings and pretty much on an as needed basis for phone conversations. I retain my affiliation with Warburg Pincus, the global private equity firm. This requires my presence in New York (generally) a couple of days a week. As I think you know, I am also Chairman of the Board of Campbell Soup Company. This entails three or four days a month.

Fortunately, I am not really "retired." This means that I have some flexibility in how I spend my time. You should feel free to call on me.

I retain my interest in and connections with the retail and apparel industry. While I am far from an expert on sourcing and production of apparel and textiles, I have some relevant experience and many friends who will do their best to keep me from looking foolish.

I will be in Baltimore and Washington for the next few days. Either you or Jean-Louis should feel comfortable in calling on my cell phone

In the interim, I will review these materials and speak again with Jean-Louis.

Regards,

Paul

text:
I wanted to tell you a couple of things for Chicago, if useful.

Norway is going to be funding and staffing a new NATO Special Rep on Women, Peace and Security and the position will be in the NATO Secretariat, which is quite significant. Moreover, Sweden is making available to NATO the Nordic Centre for Gender in Military Operations. These are both tangible new steps in promoting WPS in military operations. You have no idea what you unleashed when the US launched the National Action Plan!

Also FM Store is interested in raising the following issues with you in Chicag: Burma, Libya and Afghanistan; broader trends on women and mediation/engagement in international dialogues and peace processes, the important link between global health and efforts to address conflict-related sexual violence and ensuring that sexual violence and women's participation remains part of international dialogue with Syria.

Finally, we are looking for ways to focus the US Burma human rights groups (from simply raising the issues of on-going violence in the areas, some of it targeted on women) to actually supporting women in the ethnic conflict areas by focusing on concrete ways to enable the ethnic women to play a useful role in efforts to end the conflicts and participate in future peace agreements.

text:
Your Meeting Tomorrow with Holbrooke

Hillary:

I met with Holbrooke today on water. Pakistani military called it their third most important strategic issue. Great worries about India/Pakistan tension over 1960 agreement that regulates Indus River. We agreed our teams will work together, most likely through the World Bank supporting the Abu Dhabi Dialogue, which brings together representatives from the seven countries that share the Indus River Basin. This is the best forum we know of where India and Pakistan can meet to discuss water issues. In the context of the shared waters memo and chart I gave you last week, this ranks as potentially one of the most conflict prone, and one where the US should engage to get the parties to work together.

We are advancing well in developing a policy/action plan for you to announce on World Water Day on March 22.

Safe travels to Latin America, so glad you are going. Maria

text:
This reform will likely be criticized by some who think that putting more money in the hands of local actors will expose USAID's programs to more risk. But this is precisely the point; only by supporting local change agents—both inside and outside developing country governments—can we actually strengthen the hands of people in poor countries who are working to change their own societies for the better. That means managing risk wisely, rather than trying to avoid it altogether. And in our field research, 36 of the 39 activists we interviewed said they want USAID to support their government's directly, because it would make it easier for them to hold their governments accountable and prevent corruption.

What does all this mean? It means better aid, aid that strengthens the capacity of reformers in poor countries. And for the millions of people across the world who have been demanding these reforms, USAID has shown it is actively listening.

Sincerely,

The Aid Effectiveness Team

text:
Embassy of the United States of America The Hague, Netherlands August 3, 2011

The Honorable Hillary Rodham Clinton Secretary of State Department of State Washington, D. C. Dear Madam Secretary:

I have today informed the President that I will be stepping down as Ambassador to the Netherlands, effective September 16, 2011. To be an American Ambassador anywhere is an honor. To be Ambassador to the country of my parents' birth has been a unique privilege. The thousands of Dutch men and women I have met from all walks of life who have welcomed me and supported my work have made me even prouder of that heritage. At this time, however, I feel the need to turn more of my attention to my family and to serving the public interest closer to our home in Chicago.

I have been very proud to see how your leadership has inspired so many people in the Netherlands — both Americans and Dutch. You have set an extraordinarily high standard for effectiveness in foreign relations. I have strived to meet that standard, especially in the vital areas of equal rights and opportunity for women and girls and in protecting our environment. On both issues, the Dutch are our strong partners. I will be forever grateful for the opportunity I have had to be a part of the Obama administration on the Clinton team, working to improve our relationships all over the world.

With appreciation and a continuing commitment to the Obama Administration and your diplomatic efforts, I remain

Very truly yours,

Fay Hartog Levin Ambassador

Paul Simons called me shortly after earthquake hit Chile (8.5 Richter-- stronger than Haiti). He was going to reach out to advance team. Marriott Hotel fine. Event frightening because of intensity of tremor. Epicenter near Concepcion-- third largest city in Chile about 400 miles south of Santiago (city of Cauquenes--- hardest hit).

Just heard Bachelet on TV-- casualties so far 16-- though because communications down and it is still dark information is preliminary. Some concern over risk of Tsunami though Navy deems unlikely. Fortunately, there is no collapse of dams. Considerable damage to highway bridges and infrastructure--that will affect traffic-- in Talca hospital evacuated for precautionary reasons. President declared zones of Maule and Bio Bio disaster areas.

Significant loss of life and damage unlikely because Chile suffered devastating earthquakes in 1939 and 1960 (the strongest in recorded history) in same area so most old construction is gone. Chile has strong construction codes and state of the art anti-earthquake standards. Also Chile has excellent first responder capacity. One concern of course are aftershocks. In 1960 (May 21) a second earthquake occurred day after that caused a Tsunami in Japan. Will have to evaluate whether trip to Chile should proceed. Precisely because of tragedy this may not be time to cancel - provided Chilean side can handle and are anxious for trip to proceed. Suspect that that will be the case. Should evaluate in morning after dust settles.

Arturo

The EU meets in the coming days, and we are hoping for a strong public - and private - position on Iran. Bill has identified 5 countries that need touching to help drive a good outcome:

I know Huma has discussed with you, but a 2-minute discussion with each that underscores the key points reflected on your card would do the trick, if you can swing it.

Tx. Also, the intervention, with your modifications, turned out well. The process, in this case, did not generate a good • enough product -- I tried to make it clearer and stronger this morning and your amendments helped a lot.

text: The writer was not only a correspondent for The Guardian there but also apparently was on the Maldives delegation putting him in various rooms. The accounts from the conference have been very fragmentary, the administration has explained very little (for whatever reasons and to its detriment), and it is being widely blamed internationally. The broader lesson I draw from Chinese disrespect for the president (and US) on his trip (I've heard accounts from journalists), its behavior at Copenhagen, mercantalist economic policy (eg, currency), and its rough use of and contempt for international organizations, not to mention the strange form of Chinese neo-colonialism in Africa, is the need for policy review. Fear of Chinese retribution (economy. Iran, etc) can't be allowed to paralyze reassessment, though it should be factored into scenarios. The Europeans are being damaged worse by Chinese economic policy than us and China policy is a new area for the Western alliance to consult on. Leaving it to Treasury apparently parks policy in a laissez faire twilight zone. Treasury has been as effective on China as it has been on AIG. Just thoughts of an observer.

Qadhafi's interpreter Zlitny (who I have been talking to about the Amcits and journalists, especially Clare) called me with what he said was a message from "you know." There was clearly somebody feding him some of these lines. He repeated the line that events have changed and that the U.S. must see the situation for what it is: Hizbollah, Iran, Al-Qaeda, the revolutions in Tunisia and Egypt are all manifestations of a radical Islamic movement sweeping the region. The U.S. must use its influence to stop UK and France from the bombing. Zlitny said the Libyan Government recognizes its mistakes from the start of the crises, but believes that now the crisis (of radical Islam) is real . We must find a way out of this situation: there are misunderstandings that we can iron out. The GOL would accept a face-saving way out that includes a ceasefire and monitors. If we are ready to talk, Fuad said he would be the designated channel. I said I would pass up his message.

He said don't worry about the journalists. I urged him to let Claire call home.

text:
Dear Senator Whitehouse,

My apologies for not responding sooner to your message last night. We've received very sensitive information, the key elements of which we have been allowed to share only with the family given our contacts' security concerns. While we very much appreciate the offer by you and former Senator Specter to intervene with the Syrian leadership, we concluded that such outreach would be better left to Kofi Annan in his new capacity as UN/Arab League Special Envoy for Syria. The humanitarian situation is part of Annan's mandate, and we do not want to risk crossing wires with that effort. We were also concerned that the regime might misinterpret outreach by others as a USG attempt to open a channel of communication.

I hope this is useful, and please feel free to contact me if you have any other questions. Best, Michelle

text:
Molho informed me this morning that he could not attend the Quartet meeting on March 2 in Brussels, but could meet at a later date. He cited a conflict requiring his presence in Israel to advise the PM, a desire to consult me in advance, and lingering anger over Serry's public reference Friday to the meeting.

After consulting the Senator, I informed Molho that, in seeking delay, we would like to provide the Quartet with an Israeli commitment to meet the following week. He said that was reasonable but wanted to check with the PM. In a later conversation, he said he still thought it would be ok, but said the PM wanted to consult the FM, and he (Molho) would get back to me in the morning.

After hearing from Molho tomorrow, I plan to convene an envoys call to propose we delay both the Israeli and Palestinian meetings one week, and hold them in Jerusalem/Ramallah. I expect the others will push to proceed as planned with the Palestinians, and then meet later with Molho. So long as we can point to a confirmed Israeli meeting, I'm not sure it matters much either way, but overall more delay, the better.

I don't want to speculate on the Israeli motivation on this system.

If we postpone both meetings one week, I would go out in advance to see Molho. If the Q insists on seeing Erekat this Wednesday, I would go to that, continue my planned consultations Thursday and Friday with the French and British, and end up in Jerusalem on Sunday.

On the reunion, I wouldn't be able to do it anything til the spring because my house is small and I need the backyard. I obviously won't do it if you think it's a bad idea or would reflect badly.

But I did response for ABC News to the Republican debate last Sat night, and it just reminded me of the fact that you kicked ass in the debates and more broadly, we had a campaign that changed the country. Just thinking about NH - I mean that was historic. And at least for me, though it's taken a long time, the pain is over and I can feel pride in what we did. And I feel like if we don't take some pride in it, then it paints the whole thing as negative, when it wasn't.

I wouldn't impinge on your schedule to come. And I can see how that would create problems for you. And look, I'd be happy to take the heat. I deal w Plouffe and all these characters regularly, I know what they'll think. I'm happy to say what this is and what it isn't. But people are thinking about 4 yrs ago now because of the Rep primary - so I hate to wait til after the election. But I of course will if you prefer.

Anyway, it was great to see you. I can only imagine how exhausted you must be (now that I travel so much more for fundraising, I'm perennially exhausted!) and yet you find time to come to things like tonight - I always admire your generosity.

Merry Christmas Hillary.

Neera

text:
Report on the Goldman case and GSP

Thanks to the persistent efforts of our charge' in Brasilia, I was finally able to locate and call my counterpart, Under secretary Pedro Mendonca.

I made the points contained in your email to me — and emphasized the seriousness of the issue and Sen. Lautenberg's frustration that despite the Mr. Goldman's victories in court, he is still unable to get his son back. I said that Lautenberg had told you that in light of this, he was continuing his hold on the GSP legislation -- which, if it continues, would harm Brazil and every other developing nation.

Pedro will speak to the acting foreign minister and other authorities in Brazil right now — and will get back to me with an update and an assessment of what more can be done.

I have also spoken with my USTR counterpart Demetrios Marantis throughout the day. They have discussed this matter with the Brazilian charge' in DC. They had also organized the meeting between him and Lautenberg that Craig mentioned to you in his email -- hoping that it would lead to a lifting of the hold. Demetrios will consult with Ron Kirk to decide what more to do.

I will email you again as soon as I hear from Brasilia and/or USTR.

And I will continue to coordinate with Craig.

Bob

text:
Good Morning Everyone. Or as they say here in Israel, 'Boker Toy'

Today's a special day, not simply because the trip is almost over, but because some of us are at home among our people. In honor of that, Pam has graciously allowed me to collaborate on today's daily missive. But don't worry, by popular demand she will resume the practice starting tomorrow - even though we'll be in Washington.

Today's isn't a quote per se, and it isn't anyone famoys. These traditional questions have been asked by Jewish children for millenia. They don't necessarily have answers tough, they are merely meant to encourage children to be inquisitive.

But I am attributing the below to one very special Jewish child who I know will go on to practice and further our rich traditions:

1) Ma nishtana ha-laila ha-zeh mi-kol ha-lelot? [Why is this stop different from all other stops?]

2) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin chametz u-matza, ha-laila ha-zeh kulo matza? [Why is it that on all other nights during the year we eat well-balanced, nutritional meals with vegetables, but on this trip we eat 5000 calorie meals mixing meats and cheeses and sauces that shouldn't be combined?]

3) She-be-chol ha-lelot en anu matbilin afilu pa'am echat, ha-laila ha-zeh shetay fe'amim? [Why is it on all other nights we do not eat ice cream dipped and fried even once, but on this trip we eat ice cream that has been dipped in artery clogging batter twice?]

4) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin bayn yoshvin u-vayn mseubin, ha-laila ha-zeh kelanu mesubin? [Why is it that on all other nights we eat either sitting or reclining, but on this trip we are admonished to eat in strapped to our seats in because we are within 200 minutes of landing?]

Dear Jeff,

Thank you for the status update - we appreciate it.

In response to your question regarding assuring "accelerated declassification of all of the HAK documents in the Library of Congress, not just those that have been referred to State by the Archives", the short answer is that we cannot.

I can inquire as to whether we could consider developing a plan that is consistent with our proposal and our reviewing authorities that might enable us to work the additional collection of non-State records while we are do our State records work; such a proposal would obviously involve incremental funding based on the scope of such a plan. It also would require the engagement of other agencies. Obviously I am not certain if such a proposal could work, because as we shared in the meeting between the Secretary and HAK at their meeting, we are not in a position to address other agencies' records.

Either way, we welcome being kept apprised.

Best.

text:
Dear Colleagues,

On my last day as Deputy SRAP and DAS, I want to thank one and all for your collegiality and friendship over the past 18 months. We've achieved a lot, in my view, and I'm truly grateful to have had the opportunity to work with all of you on such critical and difficult issues, There will be other opportunities next week to say good-bye — or rather so long for now, since I hope to work again with as many of you as possible. Today I'd simply like to turn over the reins fully, after a week-long overlap, to my successor, Frank Ruggiero.

If the Senate confirm's me, I look forward to seeing you in Malaysia.

Best regards, Paul

text:
I'm writing in the hope that when you're in Afghanistan you will be able to demonstrate in some public way your support for the Afghan women. There is much disillusionment over the aftermath of the elections and the ongoing violence. It would be a wonderful signal to the women that we do value the role that they are and must continue to play to move Afghanistan forward.

Secondly, it would also be helpful because there is growing concern at home that the women are going to be abandoned. I have to meet with Sen. Casey tom'w, for example. He believes that the women are critical to stability and peace in Afghanistan and wants to discuss our commitment.

Lastly, as Pres, Karzai is beginning to plan his cabinet, perhaps you could mention to him the need to bring in some of the talented and experienced women into his government. At our Shura meeting yesterday, we discussed upcoming ministerial positions. We, of course, have no guarantee that Karzai will listen, but his government would be a lot better if he tapped women and so many are highly qualified.

Thanks.

text:
Dear Capricia,

As time moves on, I realize I haven't seen you and Mrs. Clinton (Hillary) in a long time, but I think of you both often. I don't know if movie producers are still worthy in your world, but next time you're in NYC I'd love to see you.

I have such fond memories of you guys watching SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE. I made another movie you might like about the ascendancy of King George after Edward abdicated, it's called KINGS SPEECH. The movie brings to light something that many people don't know, which is that King George was a stutterer and he hired an actor to try and help him overcome it. It's a fun movie that is much in the tradition of SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE, again I think you would both like it (and Hillary would approve because it's PG-13 with not too many swear words).

If you have any trips coming up I'd love to send it to you so you guys can watch and give me your opinion. I could also include a copy of THE TILLMAN STORY, that one is obviously not a happy film, but it's an incredibly important one.

PS

Your bad friend, Harvey PS — Please share this with Madame Secretary.

text:
I hope someone in the Administration can say something to make me feel better about today's outcome on the ATT negotiations.

In 2008 I walked up and down the streets of my rural, mostly Republican community in mid-Michigan, trying to persuade my neighbors to vote for Barack Obama. That won't be happening this year. Though I can't imagine voting for Romney, I'm so upset over the ATT outcome that I may just sit out this election. Unlike Guantanamo and the wars, this one was so easy. And they still managed not to get it right.

Somehow I hope the outcome looks better from where you sit. Susan Waltz

Susan Waltz Professor Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy University of Michigan

Margaret

text:
Please Pass to the Secretary

Madame Secretary,

A shoot out occurred on August 20 in front of the American School in Monterrey (AFSM), resulting in the death of two bodyguards. An investigation is continuing into the details, but our understanding at this point is that it was an attempted kidnapping targeting the relatives of a local business executive. While it does not appear that U.S. families were targeted, the sharp increase in kidnapping incidents in the Monterrey area, and this event in particular, present a very high risk to the families of U.S. citizens who might be become incidental victims.

U.S. security and law enforcement personnel have engaged local and federal security officials to seek their help on understanding the immediate risks and measures that can be taken. I have urged U.S. families at the Consulate in Monterrey not to send their children to school in the coming days while we review the events that took place on August 20. We also are advising U.S. citizens in the area that we have urged Consulate personnel not to send their children to school while we complete this security review.

I am sure that the warden notice will lead to a rash of press reports on U.S. concerns about security in Monterrey. More broadly, if the government cannot get the kidnappings in Monterrey under control, that may affect our ability to function in Monterrey. I have advised Secretary Espinosa of this, and have sought her help as well to address consulate security.

Consulate personnel are currently on "authorized departure" and have the option to send their families to a U.S. location. Pat Kennedy is in close touch on these matters.

Carlos Pascual

text:
As Haiti enters the period of electoral contestation, it is essential that all political actors remain calm and encourage their supporters to do the same. The United States, together with Haiti's international community partners, stands ready to support efforts to thoroughly review irregularities in support of electoral results that are consistent with the will of the Haitian people expressed in their votes.

Like others, the Government of the United States is concerned by the Provisional Electoral Council's announcement of results from the November 28 national elections that are inconsistent with the published results of the National Election Observation Council (CNO), which had more than 5,500 observers and observed the vote count in 1,600 voting centers nationwide, election-day observations by official U.S. observers accredited by the CEP, and vote counts observed around the country by numerous domestic and international observers.

Haiti's transition to democracy over the past 24 years has seen many successes, overcoming major challenges. The 2010 elections represent a critical test of whether the Haitian people will determine their destiny through their vote. The United States is committed to the consolidation of democracy in Haiti and calls on the Government of Haiti, the CEP and all political forces to ensure that the will of the people is fully reflected in the outcome of this election.

text:
Dear Anne-Marie:

As you prepare to return to Princeton, I wanted to express my gratitude for your engagement with the U.S. Navy during your tenure as Director of Policy Planning at the U.S. State Department.

I valued deeply our exchanges, and I recall with special pleasure the time you and your senior colleagues took to come to Tingey House last spring to discuss State-Navy cooperation with my team. I know you depart State with a real sense of accomplishment, especially after bringing to closure the outstanding inaugural version of the Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review.

I, of course, stand ready to support your successor and State's Policy Planning Staff, but I hope you personally will not forget us once you are back home. If the U.S. Navy or I can do anything to support you and your work, please let me know. I am well aware that your public service began long before your stint in SIP, and I am confident it will continue unbroken into the future. The Navy is eager to be a partner.

Bravo Zulu!

Very best wishes, Gary

Admiral Gary Roughead Chief of Naval Operations

Dear Secretary Clinton,

I was heartened to read your forceful remarks about the US commitment to the Asia-Pacific region this morning. On Monday, our office held a workshop for the NIC that highlighted the downsides associated with an American withdrawal from the region. I will be providing you with our report from that event. text:
Cheryl,

I know the book Dead Aid well. The ideas are not new. They are essentially the same ones that Bill Easterly has proposed in his two books: The Elusive Quest for Growth and White Man's Burden. The essential argument is that a top-down, "big-plan" approach to foreign assistance — the Jeff Sachs' approach - has not worked in the past and will not work in the future.

Both Easterly and Moyo argue for a bottom-up approach that supports overall economic growth. They emphasize expanding access to capital markets and low-cost financing, promoting better governance and accountability, policy reform to enhance foreign investment, and support for market-driven social entrepreneurs.

I will give Nora a couple of articles for you to take home and look at. One of them, by Paul Collier, offers a strong alternative to the USAID approach of funding small holder farmers. The other is by Dambisa Moyo and will give you an overall flavor of her perspective.

Matt

text:
Peggy, we should discuss further but the key points to bear in mind are as follows: The key safeguard that we are relying on to protect women's rights is the requirement that reintegrated insurgents respect the Afghan Constitution. The Constitution states that "the citizens of Afghanistan--whether man or woman--have equal rights and duties before the law" and includes special provisions (article 44 requires the state to create and foster balanced education for women; article 53 stipulates that the state must render aid to women without caretakers; and articles 83 and 84 provide quotas for women's participation in the upper and lower house respective) to encourage women's access to education and government.

It explicitly notes that the state to abide by the UN charter, international treaties, international conventions that Afghanistan has signed (Afghanistan has also ratified CEDAW which prohibits discrimination in public and private realms) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

However, article 3-- which stipulates that no law "shall contravene the tenets and provisions of the holy religion of Islam" --leaves the rights accorded to women ambiguous and up for interpretation The power of interpretation is left up to the Supreme Court, whose members often have a conservative religious training.

As witnessed in the debate over the Shiite Family Law, there is now a significant women's movement in Afghanistan which is prepared to challenge any effort to curtail women's rights. However, they continue to rely heavily on the international community to promote and protect women's rights and to create a space for their advocacy.

text:
MB MP Khaled Deeb informed me today that MB will push to review Camp David and put it to a referendum. The argument is that this would still be "respecting" Camp David, because it is Israel that supposedly violates Camp David, and the MB/Egypt will no longer tolerate it. (People who say this never cite specific examples of Israel breaking the treaty, naturally.) Making matters worse, the MB MP said he believed the reports of attacks on Israel from Sinai were invented. So walk through the chain of foreseeable events: Israel will be attacked from Sinai (this is an inevitability); it may respond; MB will claim that Israel fired first, and therefore broke the treaty, "like it always does," etc. And then the treaty, the MB will argue, is broken.

And making matter even worse: the Egyptian MFA official that I hung out with last night made the exact same argument, and similarly believed that the reports of attacks on Israel from Sinai were invented. (This particular official will be Egypt's next mission chief in Tehran, and is an ambassador.) So the MB's views on Camp David have at least some support within Egypt's diplomatic corps.

Dear Kurt,

Thank you to you and your team for your leadership in setting up today's video conference with the Secretary.

Please convey to the Secretary my personal thanks - and the deep gratitude of everyone here at US Mission NZ - for her generosity with her time and for the graciousness and power of her words.

Today's event energized our Mission colleagues, who had been feeling the usual post-crisis letdown but are now walking on air. The event also had a significant impact on our GNZ friends, who left the Chancery beaming and commenting among themselves about the extraordinary honor of being invited into the call as part of our team.

FYI, immediately upon conclusion of the call we held an awards ceremony to further thank our Kiwi friends. In front of the full Embassy audience, we called each GNZ attendee forward individually, shared an anecdote about the person's unique contribution during the immediate aftermath of the quake, and presented each Kiwi with the American Ambassador's Honor Medal. (Michele Petersen was previously presented with the Medal, and I believe she has it in her office.)

Thank you again. Today's video conference was of immense value to everyone here, and I appreciate the tireless work in DC that made it possible.

Warm regards,

text:
...I miss you a lot. And I have no idea how you keep on keeping on doing whatever it takes to lift people-everywhere upchampioning your Core Purpose of Fighting and digging deep for the opportunity for each person to be able to live up to their God Given Potential. Here and Around the world.

The struggle for an Iran that is more concerned about its people than false power. The relentless quest to stabilize the un-stable. The never give up journey to inspire and empower women and young girls to have a seat at the table of full opportunity. The pursuit for opening doors of happiness for those who struggle with the unimaginable. The steady. The Steadfast. The unwavering commitment to the dream-not the hope-but the dream of a better USA and world for all. The tough and uncompromising "pretend leaders" whom you have negotiate with. The opinion rich and caring poor arrogance of the mean spirited. The stuff that is on the news but is not really the real news.

The love and respect you give freely to all whom love life and liberty and opportunity for all. The raw respect that you have earned in the trenches of real fears, real love and real longing for a village that is Dedicated to raising a village and its children.

So I say to a beloved and dear love one-that be you-I love you. I respect you. I miss you. I cherish every moment of our remarkable journey together.

God Speed. Dear Sis. We shall cross paths soon. And until then. Onward in all things. Love RS Ride at Dawn.

text:
SIGIR gets some things wrong in its report on the Police Development Program in Iraq. For example, the $6.2 million per trainer figure is inflated by the initial start-up costs. There are a lot of other "inaccuracies" and didn't incorporate many of INL's suggestions. But SIGIR was correct on a number of points. INL made things worse by refusing to meet with SIGIR initially -- at M's recommendation, based on questions about whether SIGIR had authority to investigate this sector. Turns out they did, so they weren't well-disposed toward INL. They viewed INL's cooperation in providing documents and information as insufficient. There are always two sides to that story.

I would say though that the PDP is an Achilles heel for us. There are many uncertainties surrounding it. There was no baseline assessment done (either by DOD or by State) prior to the program. There is no implementing agreement with the Iraqis. MOT's cooperation is not 100% (the ministry does not work with contractors on an assessment, preferring official employees). There is no comprehensive plan. (What we shared with SIGIR is a plan — called Core Work Requirements -- but not a comprehensive one. There had been an attempt to create a better plan, but it kept getting outdated by the situation on the ground.) To some extent, INL is building this airplane while flying it.

The program costs $860 million, making it State's largest undertaking there. Amb. Michele Sison, formerly of Embassy Beirut, is Assistant Ambassador for the PDP and rule of law programs.

text:
Dear Hillary, Very sad days for our service. Your remarks, and those of the President, were dignified and honored the service diplomats provide the nation. Thank you and please thank the President. Chris Stevens was processing into the service as we were in the middle of Desert Shield/Storm and was no doubt influenced and inspired by the efforts of our embassies in Baghdad and Kuwait during that time. He knew the risks, and as you and the President noted, was willing to take them to make the world a little bit better. Glen Doherty was a fellow member of the Military Religious Freedom Foundation Advisory Board, which fights to ensure that our military is not further compromised by the Christian Dominionists who seek to turn it into an instrument of their religious zealotry, an army for Christ rather than for the defense of our nation. He was invaluable in helping us uncover several cases where religious indoctrination was taking place under the guise of military training. I will miss him. Thank you for your leadership at the State Department. You have been a terrific Secretary and I know you will be missed. But I also know that you will continue to provide inspiration and leadership to countless billions around the globe. Valerie joins me in sending our love during these difficult days.

With best wishes,

Joe Wilson

text: Jake: Madeline Albright very kindly called to provide a readout of a call she had today with Roza Otunbayeva, the head of the Kryrgystan provisional administration. She characterized it as a good call. Otunbayeva was pleased to talk, said she wants to restore democracy to Kyrgystan and have a government that is responsible to the people. She said she personally wants to have a "high reputation" as a result of her democracy efforts. MKA offered NDI's full assistance in organizing the elections Otunbayeva has pledged to hold in six months. Otunbayeva expressed her appreciation, but did not make any specific requests. Interestingly, Otunbayeva volunteered that Kyrgystan would keep Manas open. That is more forward leaning than what she told our Charge yesterday; she told him that they would need to review the Manas agreement but would keep it open pending that review. I thanked MKA for the readout and promised to pass it on to you. A memo and call sheet will be on its way shortly to the Secretary for her to call Otunbayeva tomorrow. Best, Bob

Dear President Martelly and Prime Minister Lamothe,

I wanted to send a quick note to congratulate you on your announcement today regarding the publication of the constitutional amendments. On behalf of the United States, we look forward to supporting your decision and to assisting as appropriate in its implementation. You have set the stage for all of the election donors to do their part in supporting the preparations for the upcoming elections; we look forward to coordinating with you and Haiti's international partners to fulfill your goal of holding municipal and senate elections by the end of November.

I wish you a safe trip to Rio and look forward to our next meeting. We remain fully committed to your government's efforts in support of Haiti's economic and social development.

Best.

cdm

text:
Dear Cheryl,

The Secretary's video message was played today on a jumbotron during the memorial service marking the first anniversary of the Christchurch earthquake.

The service was held in Hagley Park, a two-minute walk from the George Hotel. Present were the Prime Minister, the Governor General, most of the Cabinet, families of the victims, and approximately 20,000 Christchurch citizens.

The video was extraordinarily well received at the event, and it was prominently featured on the evening news reports and related websites. I received dozens of expressions of thanks at the event, including from the Prime Minister, followed by many more expressions of gratitude on our electronic media platforms.

I would be grateful if you could convey those and my personal thanks to the Secretary for recording the video despite all the other demands on her time. Her message was pitch-perfect, personal, and powerful, and it will be long remembered and appreciated here in New Zealand.

Best regards,

D

text:
Wes Clark called again. He has been approached by his same contacts, pushing for more meetings. They now want him to negotiate a ceasefire, leaving Q in country. He knows that's a non-starter and knows he can't/shouldn't play that role.

But he was in an expansive mood with me nonetheless. He thought we should consider an option where Q would have to leave "temporarily," while ceasefire and political process and dialogue issues were worked out. But we hold the door open for a possible return of Q if "the people demand it," as Mohammed Ismail keeps telling him is the case.

He also thought it's time for us to expand upon the UNSCR 1973 language and "call Qadhafi's bluff' by establishing detailed performance benchmarks that would be nominally consistent with Q's offer of a ceasefire and political process. I noted that Q's previous words about a ceasefire have been at odds with his actions on the ground. That's the point, Clark argued -- make him perform or demonstrate clearly his failure to do so. Jeffrey Feltman

text:
You will have seen Verma's note regarding Senator Menedez desire to speak to S re direct mail talks with Cuba and our follow on talks with the Cubans and dissidents. He is upset tha he was not consulted and does not think he was briefed sufficiently quickly.

WHA and H had briefed immediately on the direct mail talks, and had briefed HFAC on the follow on talks. We had asked for time to brief SFRC but had not yet done so.

This should be a good news story. We engaged with the Cubans at the Vice-Minister level, breaking a several year shunning of our Interest Section by the Cubans, traveled outside of Havana to view hurricane damage (thus breaking through the barrier of no travel beyond a ten-mile perimeter), we pursued extradition of US fugitives in Cuba, and most importantly, Bisa Williams (my DAS and the head of delegation) met with a broad range of dissidents, civil socity reps, and bloggers.

This last point is worth highlighting. The last part of the trip came together late because we would not let the Cubans condition our meetings or determine who we could or could not meet with. The Cubans finally allowed us to meet with dissidents, something they have prevented EU and other visitors from doing. In other words, we have broken th mold and put real pressure on others to do the same.

That said, our briefing and outreach could have been quicker and better coordinated. This has upset Senator Menedez. We are sending Bisa up tomorrow to brief the SFRC.

Good news: Quiet so far at Liberty today. No overnight reports of trouble.

Bad (but expected) news: the MEK is putting out the line that the transfer was inhumane and no more will occur.

Based on embassy reports and the UN draft report to UN HQ, my initial take is that (a) problems existed about personal baggage (the GOI principle that Ashrafis could take anything that any Iraqi could legally possess does not seem to have been followed in full, though much, much baggage was indeed taken to Hurriya); (b) the Iraqis seemed under orders to behave and compromise ( there are reports of one nasty Iraqi officer, but this seems to have been individual, not GOIinstructed); (c) the Iraqi search seems to have been too exacting and; (d) the Ashrafis/Hurriyaites made things more difficult through delaying tactics and deliberate confrontation, and are now playing their customary aggrieved victim role.

Take care, and on behalf of Secretary Panetta, thank you again for helping make our day yesterday.

For me, I'll be tamping down hallway chatter this morning about who might make the best next SecDef

Jeremy Bash

text:
The administration's response seems quite weak to me.

This is not like the Pentagon Papers or even the videos of the bombings, this is a wholesale capturing of the diplomatic material of the country. No State department can operate if it can't keep its own classified cables and internal orders confidential — I think this is unprecedented in history. And if this is wikileaks can get, what can the Chinese or other able to secure?

The issues surrounding the content are significant and could have legs.

But this security breach is not a targeted breach to make a whistle blower point, it is a wholesale leak that should be treated as putting lives in danger. For what it is worth, I think you need to order a full scale review and upgrading of the cyber security of the state department immediately. To offer a bounty for the capture of those responsible. And as I see you doing, take an aggressive position on Wikileaks. Just being seen as apologizing for the content is weak compared to reacting and acting to shore up the key principles behind security and aggressively dealing with the problem directly.

For what it's worth, that's my view.

Colleagues:

Further to our earlier alert, the press is widely reporting Somali gunmen disguised in army uniforms stormed a hotel popular with government officials on Tuesday, and a legislator said at least 15 parliamentarians were killed. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

The African Union confirmed at least 15 people were killed in the attack on the Huna Hotel, in a government-controlled neighborhood between the presidential palace and the Indian Ocean. It did not say whether the dead were all MPs.

Embassy Nairobi spoke with President Sheikh Sharif who confirmed that seven MPs are now dead and numerous others • are wounded. The number of attackers is not clear, but they were dressed in Transitional Federal Government military uniforms. At least two blew themselves up.

Christine P. Jackson Watch Officer Operations Center - U.S. Department of State 202-647-1512

text:
Following is close-hold please.

You will have seen press reports that Micheletti is stepping down — reportedly it will be a "leave of absence" for legal reasons. If this holds, it is an important development that we have been pushing to allow space for Pepe Lobo to get off to a good start and encourage greater attendance at the Jan 27 inauguration. This was the point of my Jan 5-6 trip to Tegucigalpa, Hugo's consistent efforts and our follow-up visa revocations. Two nights ago President Martinelli of Panama called me saying Micheletti wanted to find a way out and would he, Martinelli, talk to me. I spoke with Martinelli about ten times over the last two days to discuss specifics. Micheletti wanted to depart Friday but I told Martinelli that it had to be today because regional leaders need time to make their plans. Micheletti wanted assurances that visas would be restored, but we simply forward to Martinelli our standing press guidance that we continuously review visa decisions based on the situation on the ground. ck
