One missing piece here is leadership. Who can attract/retain/manage/hold accountable a team at the highest level. I just don't see who would be on par with Sec. Clinton in terms of that aspect.

The other missing piece is coordinating Treasury and multilateral engagement. WB and EU are probably bigger ag funders than US govt even after we start spending real money in these countries.

This is particularly true on the research, education and extension areas — and that is an area where USDA has CDC like capacity that should be leveraged aggressively. It's true that until recently USDA didn't offer this real capacity it has to anyone -- forcing people to work through the foreign ag service which is a completely different way to engage. But that is changing rapidly.

It's also true on agricultural infrastructure and marketing, where MCC brings more to the table than anyone — especially in the area of ag infrastructure.

USAID's strength should be in the country planning and country level implementation — and in this respect this initiative (even housed outside of AID)

I also suspect that in early countries we will need to identify strong leadership — which could be existing AID staff but it may be helpful to being open to finding new people at that level if needed.

This is very similar to the initial PEPFAR debate.

text:
Jake

In the past 48 hours, the political situation in Pakistan has entered a new phase. The Supreme Court ruled the NRO illegal and paved the way for prosecution of several government officials, most notably Interior Minister Rehman Malik. Malik has been summoned before the Court and the Defense Minister (along with 247 other officials) was barred from traveling to China on an official visit. Vali Nasr has been following the fast-moving and still unclear developments closely.

In addition, the Supreme Court has opened the door to new petitions to be filed, questioning Zardari's eligibility to have run for president in the first place. The Court could use those petitions to force Zardari from office in the near future. It is clear that Zardari's fate will be decided by the military, which has been gaining prominence and will be in an even stronger position after this shake-up.

In the past two days Gilani has come to Zardari's defense, suggesting the two have reached an agreement over transfer of power from president to prime minister.

I'm very pleased to announce that we've had a breakthrough in negotiations in Honduras.

I want to congratulate the people of Honduras as well as President Zelaya and Mr. Michelleti for reaching an historic ' agreement. I also congratulate Costa Rican President Oscar Arias for the important role he has played in fashioning the San Jose process and the OAS for its role in facilitating the successful round of talks.

As you know I sent Assistant Secretary Tom Shannon and his deputy Craig Kelly, and the White House NSC representative for the Western Hemisphere Dan Ristreppo to Honduras yesterday after speaking with both President Zelaya and Mr. Micheletti last Friday to urge them finally, once and for all to reach an agreement.

I cannot think of another example of a country in Latin America that having suffered a rupture of its democratic and consitutional order overcame such a crisis through negotiation and dialogue.

text:
Jake --

I recognize that we're most likely going to have a gap in the COM slot in Baghdad.

So I think that people whom the Iraqis recognize -- Tom Nides, me, Tony Blinken, etc. -- will have to increase the tempo of our travel to Baghdad for a time.

But if S is seeing Jim Jeffrey, I wonder if she could squeeze him to stay on for just a few more weeks. Not indefinitely, but, say, another month, say until May 1. There will always be bad issues in Iraq that need to be addressed, but the Syria/over flight issue seems particularly important. So I'm all in favor of minimizing the gap, even if we still end up with one. I think the only way Jim would agree to stay a few more weeks would be if the Secretary or President would ask.

Jeffrey Feltman Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State 202-647-7209

I just met with a couple of women from Libya who are part of a new ngo (they are all new), "Women for Libya". We are going to get together with a larger group in the next few weeks but I wanted to tell you a couple of points they made since I know you'll be speaking tom'w. First, Libya is a place where the US and our allies have credibility and suasion, so what we say matters. Secondly, there is only one woman in the NTC and that kind of symbolism is not sufficient if Libya's transition to a better future is going to become a reality. It is not only not going to be acceptable to the international community to marginalize the women but it should not be acceptable to Libyans to exclude half their population, many of whom were significantly engaged in supporting the uprising. The women are eager to take their place. They came in today --the way the Northern Irish did with you so many years ago-- and pleaded for support to build women's leadership capacity and to be embraced as part of a larger network. The cycle repeats itself!

text:
This is significant — Burma's two longest running insurgencies, dating back to the late 1940s (at their zenith, long since faded, Karen militia reached within miles of Rangoon). However, it's all about a change in tone, not yet a real deal. What's important is that the Burmese are using a serious, senior interlocutor (minister Aung Min, former military officer) and are backing away from their egregious Border Guard Force demands ("returning to the fold," in Burmese parlance). We are hearing from other sources that these talks are serious and genuine. There will be deal making, however — concessions, amnesties, business interests, etc — so I suspect it may take some work to secure lasting ceasefires, not to mention real accommodation. This is progress„ though — and they need to do the same with the Kachin.

Patrick

text:
On Tuesday morning the Senate will first have the cloture vote on the Cr. We will get cloture and then ask them to yield back time and vote on final passage of the Cr. We do expect them to yield back some time (how much is unclear) as the govt shut down will occur tues at midnight. Following disposal of the Cr, we will have the cloture vote on START. As we get a better sense on timing of the START cloture vote during the day on tues, I will be sure to let Huma and Lona know in case there is a chance you can come by. The vote on ratification will either be very late on wed or on thurs am, depending on whether the Republicans will yield back time.

Wyden is the only Dem expected to miss the ratification vote, but that doesn't change the number of Rs we need. Still need 9, as its 2/3rds of those present (that would be 66 if everyone except Wyden were there).

We are still working on a fairly complex missile defense amendment from Corker and McCain, but I am hopeful we can work something out short of yet another understanding in the Resolution of Ratification, which will put further pressure on the Russians to retaliate. So we are trying very hard to come up with a condition or non-binding declaration. Will keep you posted.

Finally, believe we are ready for the closed session - Feinstein, Kerry and Lugar are well briefed up.

Dear Cheryl:

I wanted to inform you about the current status of the nomination process for my re-election as President of the Bank that began on 10 May and will remain open through 24 June.

As of this date, I have been nominated by 24 countries, 20 of them regional member countries, representing 48.894 % of the voting power.

The list of countries is as follows: Argentina, The Bahamas, Belize, Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Dominican Republic, El. Salvador, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Uruguay, Trinidad and Tobago, Korea, Japon, Netherlands y Canada.

Consequently, my nomination fulfills the first requirement of nominations by at least of 15 regional member countries;

The second requirement, a majority of the total voting power of all the Bank's shareholders, is almost fulfilled as of today.(51 %)

Further, no other candidates have been nominated as of this date.

Ned Nolan (DCM in The Hague) called to give me a heads up that Fay intends to submit her resignation as Ambassador due to personal considerations -

She is planning to depart post o/a September 15.

I then called Fay myself and this is clearly a difficult decision for her as she really loves what she is doing and is torn. She is planning to call Phil tomorrow to discuss with him directly. She has already spoken to Valerie Jarrett and Bill Daley at the White House (friends from Chicago) to let them know. She has not yet told anyone at the Embassy other than Ned, and will likely let her country team know later this week or next week. In the meantime, she asked that we not spread the word too widely since she wants her folks to hear the news from her directly.

Monika - can you please reach out to Fay's assistant, Wanda Kleinsmith, to set up a time for a phone call?

Liz

text:
I thought the roll out — and particularly the Secretary's remarks — went very well. It's generating some good buzz both in the press and among the relevant diplomatic corp. It was great that the Secretary was out in front on this. As one blogger noted: "the choice of State and Secretary Clinton to present the strategy is encouraging, giving ownership to the most visible arm of administration Internet policy and situating coordination under one roof..."

The next challenge is cementing the Department's leadership role in implementing the Strategy. We are working closely with PA to amplify both the Strategy and the Secretary's leadership, following up with posts on the cable we sent on Friday, reaching out to key foreign counterparts, and working to convene appropriate groups of stakeholders — including embassy representatives, the private sector and NGOs — on the way ahead. I will keep you apprised of these activities as we move forward and, as always, I welcome any thoughts you have on how we can be most effective. Thanks.

Chris

Madame Secretary: Just a brief update. First your embassy team and young FSOs are responding heroically to the many challenges we confront in Christ Church. Every member of the dialogue and their family are accounted for. I made sure personally that all have replacement passports and return flights. There are now three unaccounted Americans in the city. We are working closely with government to get up to date and accurate information.

This is critical as already this is the worst disaster in NZ history. Over 500 buildings very badly damaged and probably over one hundred dead. Our search and rescue team are arriving on scene shortly. Am encouraging NZ to ask us for water purification as all systems are destroyed around city. Working with Ambassador Huebner to set up fund to help rebuild iconic church badly damaged in quake. Also promised NZ authorities that we will provide relevant lessons learned from Haiti. I know how overwhelming ME issues are but small gestures and steps in coming days will demonstrate our solidarity and cement new phase of our relationship. More soon Kurt

text:
Jake,

FYI — I have just returned from a meeting at DOI. This was a scheduled meeting with Tom Strickland (A/S for Fish/Wildlife and National Park Service) to discuss our efforts on many topics — e.g. CITES, Biodiversity, etc. Tom brought Sec. Salazar in to meet us and discuss a few topics. There are two issues you should know about:

1) Arctic — Sec Salazar plans to join S in Canada next week at the Arctic-5 meeting. (He is still very interested in engaging in the Arctic and does not seem to be a big fan of the Arctic Council — suggesting it is too low level. ) Regarding the meeting in Canada, we are looking for a role for Sec Salazar and think the best issue for him might be the outer continental shelf. We are going to check into this based on the current meeting agenda.

2) Sec Salazar is interested in pursuing a "peace park" linking Big Ben National Park in Texas to land in Mexico. From our discussion it seems that the land in Mexico is not yet owned by the government. Sec Salazar indicated that he has had discussions with the NSC about this, specifically in terms of President Calderon's visit in May and the state dinner. He suggested that this would be a subject of discussion during the visit. He is already planning meetings with DHS on this topic. (We are tracking down more details on the potential park.)

I am passing this on to you as Sec Salazar mentioned that he would be discussing the park and the upcoming Arctic meeting with S soon.

text:
Cheryl,

In response to your query about the possibility of going to Goma, I reached out to our colleagues in Embassy Kinshasa to see what has been done in the past. The only reasonably safe way to get to Goma is flying on a MONUC aircraft originating from Kinshasa. That would mean a two hour flight each way, leaving a very small window (probably no more than one hour) to work in events. Moreover, advancing Goma would pose a significant challenge for us for security reasons.

I also asked the Embassy to look into other ways of traveling to Goma — perhaps over land via Kigali (Lew and I had discussed this possibility earlier) — and the Embassy did not like the optics of approaching by land from another country.

We're still looking at ways to lengthen our time in Monrovia, including possibly staying overnight in another country, such as Cape Verde. Still no luck, but we're working on it...km

text:
Colleagues, Please see below from S/USSES for full update on Sudan issues. Bottom line: No major change in status. Highlights:

Abyei: Parties appear to be close to a signing a temporary agreement on the status of Abyei, but it's not yet signed. The AU is moving forward with plans to hold a signing ceremony at 1000 Addis/0300 EDT Sunday, 06/19 in hopes of calling bluffs. If the signing actually happens, S/USSES will call Ops immediately. However, S/USSES is skeptical about whether the sighing would actually take place. They noted to us that this is the third or fourth time the parties have gotten to this point.

Southern Kordofan: No movement on an agreement on cessation of hostilities in Southern Kordofan to report. The AU is reportedly considering calling for a 72-hour humanitarian ceasefire to create space for talks. Mbeki may call for this publicly tomorrow.

Earlier this evening Ambassador Lyman spoke with GoSS Minister Pagan Amum through Ops. A few highlights:

• Lyman emphasized that President Kiir told the Secretary he had approved the agreement. He said he did not want to tell the Secretary President Kiir does not speak for his government.

• Amum assured Lyman they have agreed to leave out all discussion of final status of Abyei and the agreement would be signed Sunday. Amum claimed that there was a clear understanding and the agreement would be signed with the language changed to reflect the wording from the Abyei protocols.

Regards, Colin

Adam Ereli alerted me a few minutes ago about a new SWT problem. The staff of one of Alaska's Senators called ECA this afternoon to say there is a group of Costa Rican kids working in a fish packing plant in Alaska under very poor conditions. Apparently some of the kids may have developed frostbite in their feet because the plant is so cold; presumably they did not have the right wardrobe to keep warm. The sponsor organization for these students was CETUSA, which had also sponsored the kids working at the chocolate packing plant in Palmyra. (FYI: CETUSA just this week agreed to withdraw its request for re-designation as a sponsor, when confronted with a 37-page brief from State about its many violations.)

ECA is gathering more details and promised to share them with us when they know more.

I am just reading The State of Africa — talk about depressing — geez! We seem to make the same mistakes over and over and over.

I have decided to call The Gambia "The Best Little Embassy in Africa".

I have the entire Embassy (100%) learning Wolof greetings — we started yesterday. Our instructor is one of the drivers who was a former language teacher at Peace Corps so there are no costs involved. ALSO we will start community projects next month — again 100% participation. You have to be creative with no USAID $$$$.

Shaun regrets he cannot come here tomorrow. Here's the problem and the plan: Cameron is still quietly giving encouragement to the Ulster Unionists, which, led by Reg Empey, are trying to scuttle the agreement somehow. So the plan is for Shaunn to announce he will deliver a speech on Monday in the House of Commons presenting the agreement—except that at the last second Gordon will step in on the floor for Shaun, requiring Cameron to respond, theoretically forcing him to support the agreement. In his speech, Gordon will explicitly cite your role and support of the US—among other things further cornering Cameron (and Empey). Shaun would like to speak with you soon depending on how things are working out there, perhaps tomorrow (Sunday) or perhaps Monday (perhaps after Commons). Dinner will be on a rain-check.

text:
Dear Secretary Clinton,

I am writing this note as I head for O'Hare en route to Israel-Palestine. For ten days I'll be with a small group of women to meet with both Israeli and Palestinian human rights and peace activists, with a focus on the work of women. Many things about Israel-Palestine make me very discouraged now, but I am always encouraged when I mingle with the grassroots lovers of peace and people—be they Christians, Muslims, or Jews. At those time I feel as if I have been gifted with a glimpse into God's Kingdom. So I am looking forward to this week.

The main point of this note is to offer my sympathy regarding your mother's death.

Please, Hillary, don't hesitate to ask if there is ever anything I can do for you.

For peace... Lynne

Lynne Hybels Willow Creek Community Church

text:
Just had a 30 minute call with Tony Burman head of Al Jazeera English. I registered our complaints in the strongest language possible. He started to respond by saying he knew I was concerned about their reporting of the "American" position. I interrupted him to say my concern was not about representing the American position but rather the "accurate" position of what was actually going on in Haiti. I referred him to the Sebastian Walker interview and Hs interview with Anand Naidoo. I said the former was almost laughable if it were not so serious. He promised to take a look at it and email me. He then told me that they had made an effort to broaden the coverage. He also referred to pieces in the NY Times and International herald tribune which also focused on comments from Brazilians and MSF. I pointed out that perhaps the bigger story was that with so many international organizations involved it was astonishing that so few had complaints. I reiterated the points that everything is being done in cooperation with and at request of GOH; that security is being handled under direction of UN; that we would make USG reps available to them for on record comments; etc. He said that Walker had tried but been unable to get comments from US Military. Frankly I think we need to be careful about making military available to them since that may reinforce the negative perceptions but PJ and Price should make that call.

Can someone please email me Gordon's contact info in PoP so I can email it to Burman. Also names and info of anyone else in PoP they should contact if they need comments.

JM

Whether we have a lot to say or a little to say, this will be a global media event and the State Department spokesman will not be there. I do understand our strategy, that we are going to keep our words sparse, given the sensitivity of the negotiations. When I hesitated and said I was not sure and then explained that we were making a deliberate calculation regarding our PD strategy, he then remarked that this means the media will have a painful four days in the region because the assumption is there will be nothing provided them. text:
As I mentioned last week, I was on a panel at the Brussels forum with Lady Ashton (who insisted everyone call her Cathy), Estonian president Toomas lives, and Senator Voinovich. Ashton and I essentially reinforced each other at every turn and presented a very positive vision of US-EU partnership. She has scored some significant victories lately, most notably that development will be included in the European Action Service (EAS) rather than sitting at a separate desk (the formula we are seeking rather than the DFID formula). EU defense staff will also be included in the EAS. Indeed, Ashton chairs the European Council whenever the 27 foreign ministers, development ministers, or defense ministers meet -- the ultimate integrated frame. She also has control over a number of the smaller development and statebuilding budgets, though I gather the biggest development fund is still in dispute between her and the development commissioner. Apparently, however, the enlargement commissioner took his cues from her on strategy and policy and then presented his implementation plans to the Council, which is the role she wants. We should be able to build on the way the EU is organizing in pushing pushing our own integrated frame here.

I hope everything goes well on Ottawa and NY. Bob Hormats and I will send a note on other aspects of Brussels forum, where US was well represented. AM

text:
Cheryl:

Are we in a good place to begin paperwork to bring Jen Davis up here on TDY in October?

If so, I would recommend we ask her to report on October 29 and I will get the EX office to start the paperwork. She will be detailed to us for 90 days, which will enable her to receive funding for housing, meals + incidentals, etc., and this 90 day period will carry her through the end of the term on January 20, 2013. This schedule would give me 10 days or so of consultation before a desired departure for Vienna on November 14.

I am not intent on rushing out to Vienna; the closer we get the more there is to be done, and we may not get ourselves "packed out" before we depart (not a wholly unwelcomed outcome, since we can set aside that task for December or January). But, if the elements are in place, Carol and I would like to go out mid-November in order to participate in IAEA meetings on November 26-30.

My swearing-in ceremony is scheduled for November 9 at 10am on the 8th floor. Whatever plan we embrace, that date is set and Carol and I are eager for the day.

text:
The Jerusalem city council is set to review the Kings Garden/Gan Hamelech/Bustan plan tomorrow. Recall that the plan received approval by a municipal sub committee in late June. The entire city council must now review and approve the plan because of an administrative appeal filed against it by a Meretz city council member (this appeal process requires that the entire city council review the plan at some point.) Lots of other details here that Jerusalem will be including in a front channel cable. Amanda Pilz, CCed here, drafted.

Bottom line though is that (1) this is on the agenda at the explicit direction of the Mayor and deputy mayor and (2) there is no statutory or other need for this review tomorrow.

Also note that this is not the final step in the process. After full Jerusalem municipal approval the plan must go to Ministry of Interior bodies. So there is a whole lot of theater involved in this.

Lastly, recall that the Gan Hamelech plan involves extensive demolitions and the redevelopment of Bustan, a section of the Silwan which is a stone throw away from the Old City. (When S made her comments on demolition in November 2009 she was referring to Bustan demolitions)

Best, Alon

COMMUNIQUE

During their telephone conversation last week, the President of the Republic and President Obama expressed the resolute commitment of our two countries in Haiti, and decided to combine their efforts in order to deal with the urgent humanitarian situation and to respond, in the future, to the enormous reconstruction requirements.

Cheryl-- don't know if you remember me. We worked together in the Clinton WH. I worked at the NSC for Sandy and Tony and worked a lot with Pat Griffin. I kept a Dem foreign policy list for the past 8 years or so, circulating national security op-eds and articles by Dems to Dems. I'm now working for Leon Panetta at the CIA. but I am not writing to you in that capacity. This is my own initiative

He is a terrific officer and person. He has spent his career in WHA. He was born in Puerto Rico and is fluent in Spanish. He is smart, level headed and very loyal. He would do an excellent job. I am not trying to interfere, but he is such a superb officer and good person that I thought it was important for you to take consider him seriously. Please let me know if you need any additional information. I have know Alex for 35 years, so I am sure I can answer almost all questions. Hope all is well. The Secretary is doing a great job. Bill Danvers

text:
Thanks, Cheryl We know we can count on your support. We'll talk in the morning. We're very concerned over our injured officers and moving heaven and hell to get to them.

The UN was hit MUCH worse than us. No work on The UN is flying in medevacs early and hopes to start ferrying its injured and dead from the headquarters to the airport where they are setting up a temporary hospital/morgue. The city is chaotic with traffic jams, rubble, and lots of dead bodies. No reports yet of violence, but looting has begun. MINUSTAH is focused totally on trying to rescue people from their crumbled headquarters. The Canadian Embassy was severely damaged. We are getting HUGE aftershocks every 20-30 minutes that bring down more rubble and are rattling everyone's nerves. I'll be working on a list tonight for ordered departure and hope to have a recommendation for the Department at 7:30. Thanks for your support! David

text:
All,

The President of the General Assembly (PGA) just announced the results of the first round of voting. Countries need to receive votes from at least 2/3 of the UN Member States present and voting in the General Assembly to win a seat. All 193 UN Member States were present and voting, so 129 is the required to win seat.

African Group (2 seats) • Mauritania 98 (proceeding to 2"d round) • Morocco 151 [ELECTED] • Togo 119 (proceeding to 2"d round)

Asian Group (1 seat) • Kyrgyzstan 55 • Pakistan 129 [ELECTED] (NOTE: Minimum # of votes needed) • Fiji 1— previously announced candidacy, but then rescinded

Eastern European Group (one seat) • Azerbaijan 74 (proceeding to 2' round) • Hungary 52 • Slovenia 67 (proceeding to 2nd round)

Group of Latin American and Caribbean States (1 seat) • Guatemala 191 [ELECTED] (2 abstentions)

The 2"d round (and 3rd rounds) of voting are restricted to the top two (in the case of 1 avail seat) vote recipients in the first round. The Eastern European Group will go to a rd round of voting, with Slovenia and Azerbaijan on the ballot. The African Group will go to the 2"d round as well, with Mauritania and Togo on the ballot.

The 2nd round of voting is starting now.

Dan

Fyi, he spoke with Robert Ford today.

Mentioned that he spoke to SecDef re what we are doing and what we should be doing.

He pressed Robert for his view on whether we should, as a normative matter, send more arms in. He also asked about the radicalization of the opposition and how we can mitigate this trend.

Bottom line, sounds like Corker is trying to figure out his position on this issue, and he's looking for guidance from us on how to think about this, and what our policy should be.

Anyway, not sure if S connected with him, but wanted to flag this for you.

text:
Tamera - - I would be very grateful if you could pass on the following message to Sec. Clinton:

Dear Secretary Clinton,

Phyllis and I have been very concerned since learning of your fall and concussion several weeks ago, and are now more acutely alarmed over your hospitalization for a blood clot.

Please know that we are thinking of you and that you are in our prayers - - and praying is one thing that I am pretty good at!

Most sincerely, we wish you a full and speedy recovery and hope you are able to return to your regular routine in short order.

Please accept our best wishes for a 2013 filled with good health, joy, success and peace.

Warm regards and Shalom,

Michael

Michael S. Miller Executive Vice President and CEO Jewish Community Relations Council of New York 225 West 34th Street, Suite 1607 New York, NY 10122 W: 212-983-4800, ext. 130 F: 212-983-4084 www.jcrcny.org

text:
Reporting in

We successfully concluded our apec summit. Matvienka presided for Russia and the delegates competed with each other to show they were implementing the SF declaration. It's amazing to hear what's been achieved in just one year! Amb Klem who attended all the apec meetings this year said it was by far the liveliest and most constructive. The Russian dep FM closed the summit and apologized for all the scheduling challenges and said he hoped all worked out to your satisfaction in the end. This was a critical passage for the institutionalization of women and the economy into Apec, and I'm glad Russia was able to deliver. Thx for solidifying all of this. Many of the delegates referred to what you said in SF and how they were heeding your call.

text:
I thought I would share this heartfelt message from Patricia Lamego de Teixeira Soares, the head of Brazil's Central Authority, the office responsible for Hague Convention abduction cases. You will see that in spite of our efforts to protect the son, the Brazilian family chose to make a spectacle outside the Consulate this morning by parading Sean through a crowd. Ms. Lamego recently visited the U.S. where she met with members of Congress and others to explain all that the Brazilian Central Authority was doing to reunite Sean and his father under the Hague Convention. The delays we saw in this case were largely the result of a wealthy, well connected family able to influence court decisions.

We are all relieved and thrilled to see this long overdue but very happy ending. I should also highlight the amazing work done by US Mission Brazil. The consular staff, Charge, Acting DCM (Marie Damour, the Consul General in Brasilia), LegATT, RSO, and a host of others all played a role in this successful return. My OCS DAS, Michele Bond, and her dedicated team also played a big role in communicating with David, his lawyers, Congress, and the press. We had Members of Congress, former Assistant Secretaries and US Ambassadors all pitching in. While there were disagreements at times over tactics, we all agreed that we were working towards the same goal: the safe return of Sean.

We particularly appreciate the strong support from the Secretary. Many people will try to take credit for today's happy reunion but it was the Secretary's continued concern and interest in this case that made the difference. We could not have provided a better gift to David Goldman during this season of giving. Janice

text:
Hi Cheryl,

I thought that it might end up not being possible to have the chance to say hello today. Completely understandable. But sorry I missed you and I will look forward to whenever I see you in the future.

I should mention how much I love attending the Women of Courage Awards event. I think it is my favorite event to attend each year because it is so inspirational and, for me, energizing. Year after year the women who are celebrated are incredibly brave. It is a reminder of what the personal stakes are for real people in their own countries. And their illumination of unfathomable courage day-to-day distinguishes not only them but also this event in a meaningful way from a lot of things that I've attended over the years. So I must say thank you to the people in the State Department who let me attend this each year!

Take care Cheryl!

Cheers, Steve
